Residents /Visitors are required to quarantine at home or in their accommodation until they receive a negative arrival test.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201028234041/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-travellers   http://web.archive.org/web/20201028235035/https://bm.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/

Visitors must sign an agreement to abide by legal requirement to quarantine in your accommodation until you receive a negative arrival test result.  Residents without a valid negative, pre-departure COVID-19 PCR test result must quarantine until they receive results from their day 8 COVID-19 PCR test.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201109220826/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-travellers

Speaking at last night’s [Nov 17] press briefing, Minister Wilson said, “It is anticipated that in the near future, arriving visitors will have to secure a negative PCR pre-departure test that is no older than 5 days prior to arrival in Bermuda.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201119143316/http://coronavirus.bernews.com/minister-covid-test-rules-to-change-to-5-days/
http://web.archive.org/web/20201029004014/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus

Mask must be worn at anytime physical distance of 6 ft or 2 meters cannot be maintained from others. You do not need to wear a mask when at home, when exercising or if a child under the age of 2.  Mask Guidelines - http://web.archive.org/web/20201029004811/https://www.gov.bm/mask-guidance

When to wear a mask:  1. Workers at all workplace premises should wear masks - Frontline staff (e.g food handlers, cashiers), Those performing backend functions (e.g. data entry, payroll etc.),  2. If you leave the house to purchase essentials or for work: Wear a mask  3. While taking public transport or in taxis  4. At the grocery store  5. At anytime physical distance of 6 ft or 2 meteres cannot be maintained from others  You do not need to wear a mask when at home, when exercising or if a child under the age of 2.     Masks Guidance: http://web.archive.org/web/20201109222638/https://www.gov.bm/mask-guidance
School policy is still dictated by provinces, and thus varies, but using the example of universities in Newfoundland, there are no in person classes, qualifying it as 2T.

All schools in Nunavut must close from the 18th of November and education will be conducted online.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201121180913/https://www.gov.nu.ca/health/news/nunavut-moves-territory-wide-covid-19-restrictions

Highly territorial, but Winnipeg recently closed certain sectors like Casinos and recreational facilities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109200337/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/winnipeg/index.html#wmr_restrictions

Beginning November 18th for a 2 week period in Nunavut, all non-essential services, business and organisations will be required to close and wherever possible, switch to work from home.  All recreation facilities will be closed, all restaurants become take-out only, and bars will be closed. All personal services such as hairstylists and masseuses must close.   All health centres and the Qikiqtani General Hospital are closed except for emergency services.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201121180913/https://www.gov.nu.ca/health/news/nunavut-moves-territory-wide-covid-19-restrictions

Restrictions vary by province, but certain places, like "red areas" in Quebec continue ban public events  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109204328/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/progressive-regional-alert-and-intervention-system/level-4-maximum-alert-red/

Restrictions vary by province, but certain places, like "orange areas" in Quebec continue to cap gatherings at 6.  Winnipeg has recently lowered their gathering size to 5 to counteract the spike.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109200337/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/winnipeg/index.html#wmr_restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109200035/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/progressive-regional-alert-and-intervention-system/level-3-alert-orange/

For a 2 week period in Nunavut from the 18th November, outdoor gatherings over 5 people are no longer permitted. Indoor gatherings are restricted to 5 people in addition to household members.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201121180913/https://www.gov.nu.ca/health/news/nunavut-moves-territory-wide-covid-19-restrictions
Public transit remains open.
The federal government continues to advise people to stay at home.

Travel and quarantine restrictions are varied by province, the most extreme of which continues to be the outright ban for those outside the maritimes to enter Newfoundland.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201109204109/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/travel-restrictions/
No change.
As noted before, policy was extended. No change.

On the 19th of November, Bill C-9 received royal assent. This includes the extension of the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy until June 2021. This remains at the current rate of up to 65% of eligible wages.
As noted before, policy was extended. No change in debt relief

On 19th of November, Bill C-9 received royal assent. This includes the new Canada Emergency Rent Subsidy. This will support businesses, charities and non-profits that have suffered revenue drop by providing support up to 65% of eligible expenses until December 19th 2020.   A new Lockdown support also provides an additional 25% through the Canada Emergency Rent subsidy for qualifying organisations that are subject to lockdown and must shut their doors under a public health order. Combined, these two measures mean businesses subject to lockdown could receive rent support of up to 90%.   https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/news/2020/11/new-targeted-support-to-help-businesses-through-pandemic-receives-royal-assent.html

On November 10th, the Minister of Public Services and Procurement and Minister of Health announced that the Government has signed an agreement with BD to purchase 7.6 million rapid, point-of-care, antigen tests and up to 2,172 analysers.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201120222633/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-services-procurement/news/2020/11/government-of-canada-signs-another-agreement-for-covid-19-antigen-rapid-tests.html

While many places like Toronto, Quebec, and Manitoba are requiring masks at all indoor spaces, however certain places in New Brunswick, like Moncton, have gone further, requiring it in all public spaces. Outdoor single family yards are exempt  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109205125/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/moncton-campbellton-masks-mandatory-outside-1.5759496  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109200337/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/winnipeg/index.html#wmr_restrictions

According to the latest data from Edweek's tracker, some US states (inducing Hawaii, California, and West Virginia) mandate school closures in some parts of their states due to the risk of infection. Some US territories (Washington DC, Puerto Rico) continue with full closures.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108171154/https://www.edweek.org/ew/section/multimedia/map-covid-19-schools-open-closed.html?cmp=eml-enl-eu-mostpop&M=59726363&U=&UUID=96155749d7cc9a7eb4e153ce431f8907

The central govt does not recommend school closings. According to a press briefing by VP Pence and members of the Coronavirus Task Force on 19 Nov: "it is the position of this task force, of this administration, and of the CDC that we do not need to close our schools." https://web.archive.org/web/20201121183220/https://www.edweek.org/ew/section/multimedia/map-covid-19-schools-open-closed.html    However, at state level, different decisions have been taken. Edweek reports full closures for DC and Puerto Rico, partial closures for Michigan, New York, West Virginia, Delaware, North Carolina, Oregon, California, New Mexico, Hawaii. https://web.archive.org/web/20201121183241/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/press-briefing-vice-president-pence-members-coronavirus-task-force-november-19-2020/

NYT tracker shows substantial reopening since last note. Nevertheless, some businesses, particularly bars, remain closed in certain states (ex: TX, CA, NM)  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108172558/https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/states-reopen-map-coronavirus.html

Effective from Nov 16, several states tightened their restrictions. New Mexico is one of the strictest, requiring all but essential business to close until Nov 30. Essential businesses, including grocery stores, cannot exceed 25 percent capacity or 75 customers at one time. Oregon started a 2-week lockdown on Nov 18, also requiring nonessential business to close.     New Mexico: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123192402/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/frequently-asked-questions/  Oregon: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123193338/https://govstatus.egov.com/OR-OHA-COVID-19

Some jurisdictions (e.g. some areas of California) require events to be cancelled if criteria on cases are not met. Most states require events to proceed with distancing and other sanitary precautions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108172808/https://www.northstarmeetingsgroup.com/News/Industry/Coronavirus-states-cities-reopening-COVID-19-new-cases

In some states public events are allowed to go ahead, while others have very tight restrictions in place that do not allow for public events. California had a ban on all gatherings until Nov 12, and from Nov 13 onwards allowed outdoor gatherings of max 3 households in the counties with the strictest regulations (applies to 41 out of its 58 counties). In New Jersey, general indoor gatherings must be limited to 10 people. All attendees at indoor gatherings must wear face coverings and stay six feet apart. There are several exceptions where the rule is 150 people or 25% of a room's capacity -- whichever number is lower. General outdoor gatherings must be limited to 150 people and social distancing must be practiced. (Though there is no limit for outdoor gatherings for wedding ceremonies, funerals, memorial services, religious activities, or political activities.) In New Mexico, gatherings of up to 5 people are allowed.    California: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123193657/https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Guidance-for-the-Prevention-of-COVID-19-Transmission-for-Gatherings-November-2020.aspx  New Jersey: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123193834/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/reopening-guidance-and-restrictions/how-can-people-safely-get-together-what-are-the-limits-for-indoor-and-outdoor-gatherings  New Mexico: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123192402/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/frequently-asked-questions/

Hawaii appears to have the strictest gathering limits in the nation, with gatherings of over 10 people not permitted. Some other states, like Connecticut, limit gatherings of over 25.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108172834/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html

Alabama, Idaho, Indiana, Missouri and South Dakota allow gatherings of any size, while other states have very strict measures in place. The most restrictive are New Mexico with max 5 people and Oregon with max 6 people from max 2 households.     Overview (last updated Nov 17): http://web.archive.org/web/20201123193939/https://www.northstarmeetingsgroup.com/News/Industry/Coronavirus-states-cities-reopening-COVID-19-new-cases  New Mexico: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123192402/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/frequently-asked-questions/  Oregon: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123193338/https://govstatus.egov.com/OR-OHA-COVID-19
Public transit systems throughout the country are open but often operate with restrictions.
Across the country, public transport is operating but at reduced capacity.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201123194911/https://time.com/5869375/public-transit-coronavirus-covid/
No state currently enforces a stay-at-home order, but some continue to recommend doing so.

On Nov 16 Chicago and New Mexico issued a stay-at-home order, under which people are only allowed to leave the house for emergencies or essential needs such as grocery shopping. California has imposed a curfew in most of its counties.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201123192402/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/frequently-asked-questions/
States like New York require visitors from non-contiguous states to quarantine upon arrival.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108173014/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-travel-advisory
Various states have quarantine requirements upon arrival from another state.     Overview: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123200438/https://www.kayak.com/travel-restrictions/united-states
The United States continues to prevent arrivals from certain countries. https://web.archive.org/web/20201108173016/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html

With specific exceptions, foreign nationals who have been in any of the following countries during the past 14 days may not enter the United States: China, Iran, European Schengen area, United Kingdom, Republic of Ireland, Brazil.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201123200604/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
Funds continue to be available for some programmes.

Evictions relief continues until 1 January.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108190335/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-eviction-declaration.html

In several states, facial coverings are required whenever distancing is impossible (NC, OH, and many others). In Nevada, mask-wearing is always required outside the home.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108190507/https://www.aarp.org/health/healthy-living/info-2020/states-mask-mandates-coronavirus.html#Nevada

Masks are mandatory in the majority of states: http://web.archive.org/web/20201122093458/https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/states-reopen-map-coronavirus.html. In Massachusetts they must be worn in any public space, regardless of whether social distancing measures can be adhered to: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123201736/https://www.mass.gov/news/mask-up-ma
